author: Starkville Daily News
title: Hyaluronic Acid Raw Material Market Forecasted to Reach USD 10.8 Billion by 2030 with Notable CAGR of 6.5% - ResearchAndMarkets.com | News | starkvilledailynews.com
text:
The "Hyaluronic Acid Raw Material Market Size, Share & Trends Analysis Report By Application (Ophthalmology, Orthopedics), By Source (Non-Animal, Animal), By Grade, By Region, And Segment Forecasts, 2023 - 2030" report has been added to ResearchAndMarkets.com's offering.
The global hyaluronic acid raw material market size is expected to reach USD 10.8 billion by 2030. The market is expected to expand at a CAGR of 6.5% from 2023 to 2030. The increasing use of hyaluronic acid in various medical applications, such as osteoarthritis, wound healing, postoperative adhesion, tympanic membrane repair, tumor diagnosis, fracture healing, and soft tissue repair is expected to fuel the market growth over the forecast period.
The orthopedics segment dominated the overall market in 2015 with the highest revenue generation. The increasing geriatric population base, rising incidence of osteoarthritis, and growing adoption of viscosupplements in the treatments contribute to the large market share of this segment. Furthermore, the drug delivery segment is projected to be the fastest growing over the forecast period with a significantly higher CAGR. The increasing R&D activities focusing on targeted drug delivery systems and growing usage of hyaluronic acid in anti-cancer drug delivery is expected to contribute to the market growth.
The increasing women population of age 35 to 65 years across the globe engenders a greater demand for anti-aging cosmetic and aesthetic treatments. Owing to the distinctive viscoelastic and moisturizing properties coupled with lower toxicity levels offered by hyaluronic acid-based products, the demand for this polymer in dermal fillers as well as in the treatment of vesicoureteral reflux is expected to experience growth. Thus, it is anticipated that the need for such products will serve as a high impact driver for the hyaluronic acid products over the forecast period. Based on the statistics of the International Society of Aesthetic Plastic Surgery in 2014, there were approximately 20 million cosmetic procedures performed globally, of which nearly 13.5% of the procedures were HA-based non-surgical procedures.
Some of the top countries recording a majority of the aesthetic treatments in 2014 were the U.S., Brazil, Japan, South Korea, Mexico, Germany, France, and Colombia. Medical tourism for cosmetic surgery in the U.S. plays a very important role in aiding the uptake of HA-based products and procedures, which is expected to drive the market in the coming few years.
Hyaluronic Acid Raw Material Market Report Highlights
The orthopedics segment dominated the market in 2022 with the largest revenue share of 39.7% owing to the growing adoption of technologically advanced drugs coupled with the wide usage of hyaluronic acid in the treatment procedures of osteoarthritis. The introduction of FDA-approved hyaluronic acid-based viscosupplements such as ORTHOVISC and MONOVISC is expected to boost usage over the next 8 years Some of the key market players are Salix Pharmaceuticals; ALLERGAN; Lifecore Biomedical, LLC; Anika Therapeutics, Inc.; Smith & Nephew; Maruha Nichiro Corporation; Ferring B.V.; SEIKAGAKU; F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd., Zimmer Biomet; and others Key Attributes:
Report Attribute Details No. of Pages 120 Forecast Period 2022 - 2030 Estimated Market Value (USD) in 2022 $6.61 Billion Forecasted Market Value (USD) by 2030 $10.8 Billion Compound Annual Growth Rate 6.5% Regions Covered Global

author: Hannoversche Allgemeine Zeitung
title: Tomorrowland: Flammeninferno zerstört Hauptbühne des Techno-Festivals
text:

Flammeninferno in Belgien: Hauptbühne des Tomorrowlands abgebrannt
Zwei Tage vor Beginn des Elektrofestivals Tomorrowland im belgischen Boom ist auf der Hauptbühne ein Feuer ausgebrochen.

author: Germán González,J. G. Albalat
title: L'església evangèlica va apartar el pastor de Terrassa per abusos
text:
Pederàstia
L’església evangèlica va apartar el pastor de Terrassa per abusos
La Federació d’Entitats Religioses Evangèliques exercirà d’acusació popular en el cas obert per les denúncies d’agressions sexuals en la congregació.
La Federació d’Entitats Religioses Evangèliques d’Espanya (FEREDE) va retirar el 2022 l’acreditació per predicar a José García, el pastor de l’Església Samaria de Terrassa, després de rebre la informació que diverses feligreses asseguraven haver sigut abusades sexualment per ell, segons han confirmat a EL PERIÓDICO representants legals del Consell Evangèlic de Catalunya, la sectorial catalana de la federació estatal. En conversa amb aquest diari, el pastor ha negat aquesta acusació i ha mantingut que havia deixat de predicar per qüestions de salut.
Segons el Consell Evangèlic, també el 2022 es va retirar l’acreditació a l’església com a centre de culte, ja que també van rebre notícies sobre presumptes agressions sexuals a diverses menors comeses pel responsable d’activitats lúdiques, T. A., qüestió que ara està sent investigada per un jutjat de Terrassa. "En una reunió amb el consell vam explicar el que ens havia passat i no vam rebre cap tipus de suport. Fins i tot vam comentar que estàvem en tractament psicològic. Al final de la trobada, l’únic que ens van dir és: ‘Resarem’", qüestiona Josué Soler, una de les víctimes. Les autoritats evangèliques han explicat a aquest diari que el 2022 no van denunciar els fets perquè ho havien de fer els afectats.
Acció popular
Però no ha sigut fins ara, quan els casos han transcendit, que el consell ha anunciat que es personarà en el procediment per presumptes agressions sexuals dins de la comunitat Samaria d’aquesta localitat. En concret, aquesta entitat ha donat instruccions als seus serveis jurídics per exercir l’acció popular i poder acusar les persones implicades en aquests delictes, tant les que han sigut denunciades com d’altres que hi podrien estar presumptament relacionades.
Amb aquesta actuació, el consell afirma que actua "en defensa de les persones perjudicades" i expressa "tolerància zero" pels causants d’aquestes situacions. "Tal com ja es va fer al seu dia, a part de condemnar els fets denunciats, volem expressar la nostra més ferma condemna a qualsevol forma d’abús, sigui quina sigui", afirmen ara.
També l’Església Evangèlica Unida de Terrassa ha condemnat de manera "rotunda" qualsevol cas d’abús sexual comès a Samaria i es desvincula "completament d’aquesta comunitat i dels fets que se li atribueixen". "Volem deixar clar que tot això no representa la comunitat protestant de Terrassa".

author: Amy Bounds
title: Longmont’s Trail Ridge Middle students present first Unified Theater performance – Longmont Times-Call
text:
Longmont’s Trail Ridge Middle School is expanding its Unified programs by creating the district’s first middle school Unified Theater program.
Student Fernando Arroyo plays a pixie in Trail Ridge Middle School’s first Unified Theater show. He and the other actors rehearsed Thursday at the school. (Cliff Grassmick/Staff Photographer) Trail Ridge drama teacher Lindsay Sullivan said she wanted to build on the school’s successful Unified sports program and used the inclusive theater programs at Frederick and Niwot high schools as models. As in other Unified programs, general education students are paired with students with disabilities as mentors.
“Theater is for everyone,” Sullivan said. “Theater is a place where every kid, regardless of their abilities, can find community and talent and acceptance. The more inclusive we are, the more amazing things we can create. I’m really proud of what the students have done.”
The program’s first production, “The Enchanted Garden,” will debut at 5 p.m. Friday at the school, 1000 Button Rock Drive. The fairytale-themed play, written by Sullivan, celebrates friendship and kindness with roles tailored to highlight the strengths of each student actor.
Sullivan said she asked students in the Unified program what kind of story they wanted to see, and the consensus was a fairy tale. Her play tells the story of best friends Luna and Soren, who leave their small village to enter an enchanted forest so they can make a wish for more friends. After making friends with a pixie, wind spirit and firefly, they no longer need to wish for new friends because they’ve already found them.
She kept the play short, at about 25 minutes. To accommodate students with physical challenges, the play uses limited set pieces. Some actors also have simplified lines and, in one case, an actor has a student helper to read lines to him if needed.
Along with drama students and students in the Unified club, the school’s new theater tech class is helping with the production. Altogether, about 20 students are involved.
Seventh grader Elijah Young is the assistant director for “The Enchanted Garden” and previously acted in other Trail Ridge plays.
“I’ve always wanted to see what it was like to be a director,” he said. “I’ve always wanted to help out on stage.”
While helping direct can be challenging because “there are some goofballs” in the production, he’s enjoying his role. He added that he was a little nervous initially about working with students with disabilities, but quickly realized “they were just normal people, so I talk to them like normal people.”
“I hope we can inspire other middle schools that they can do this,” he said.
Avery Howard, left, and Hero Martin, rehearse a scene on Thursday at Trail Ridge Middle School in Longmont. (Cliff Grassmick/Staff Photographer) Eighth grader Avery Howard, who is playing Luna, has been a student mentor in the Unified program since sixth grade. She said she found out about the program from her mom, who is one of the school’s special education teachers. Her advice to her Unified partner in the play is to “pretend you’re a princess.”
“It’s been really fun,” she said.
Seventh grader Vivian Sebring, who is part of the tech crew, said she took a tech theater class because “I like making stuff happen.” She added she appreciates how easygoing the actors with disabilities are during rehearsals.
“If they make a mistake, they’re like ‘oops,’ and try again,” she said.
Classmate Mal Brickley, who is helping with lights, sound and props, said there were a few technical malfunctions during the dress rehearsal, “but it’s nothing we can’t fix.”
“A Unified play is a great way to include all of our community,” Mal said.

author: Katy Hayes
title: Too big a story squashed into too small a shape
text:
Too big a story squashed into too small a shape
'The Baby’s Room' at Galway International Arts Festival feels thinner than previous ‘Rooms’ instalments, leaving lots of gaps
This is the 12th year of the ‘Rooms’ project, a series of 15-minute audio plays written and directed by Enda Walsh and designed by Galway International Arts Festival’s artistic director Paul Fahy.
This ongoing project is something of an institution, and a curious measure of Walsh’s writing development.
Have you tried Focail and Conundrum?
Daily word puzzles designed to test your vocabulary and lateral thinking skills.

author: , The Indianapolis Star
title: The first severe case of H5N1 bird flu confirmed in US: What to know about the virus
text:
The first severe case of H5N1 bird flu confirmed in US: What to know about the virus
The confirmation comes weeks after the first case of bird flu was found in a child in California, according to the CDC.
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) confirmed the first case of "severe" [avian influenza](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/health/2024/12/18/louisiana-bird-flu-patient-severe-symptoms/77074515007/), commonly known as [bird flu](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/health/2024/12/18/bird-flu-cows-dairy-person-infected/76989489007/), less than a month after a child in California was diagnosed with the virus.
On Friday, the CDC confirmed a person from Louisiana had avian influenza A virus, [H5N1](https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2024/m1218-h5n1-flu.html), after they were exposed to sick and dead birds in a backyard flock, according to a CDC press release. The patient was hospitalized, marking the first "severe" human case in the United States.
"While an investigation into the source of the infection in Louisiana is ongoing, it has been determined that the patient had exposure to sick and dead birds in backyard flocks," the CDC said in a statement. "This is the first case of H5N1 bird flu in the U.S. that has been linked to exposure to a backyard flock."
The confirmation comes weeks after the first case of bird flu was [found in a child in California](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/health/2024/12/18/bird-flu-cows-dairy-person-infected/76989489007/). This year, 61 people in the U.S. have been infected with bird flu, [according to the CDC. ](https://www.cdc.gov/bird-flu/situation-summary/index.html)
What is bird flu?
Bird flu, also known as avian influenza, is a virus that can sometimes spread from infected animals, like birds and cows, to humans, according to the[ Cleveland Clinic.](https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/22401-bird-flu#diagnosis-and-tests) The virus primarily infects birds
There are multiple subtypes of the bird flu, but H5 subtypes of influenza A are the most common.
The two most common types of avian influenza are the following, according to Cleaveland Clinic:
- Influenza A(H5N1)
- Influenza A(H7N9)
In which states have people been infected by bird flu?
Which animals are most likely to be infected?
Poultry are most likely to have avian influenza, according to the CDC's data. Around 123 million poultry have been affected since 2022 in all 50 states.
Since Match 2024, [over 700 herds of dairy cows ](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/health/2024/12/06/bird-flu-usda-bulk-raw-milk-testing/76823852007/)have also been affected in 16 states.
Zoo animals infected, some killed, in Phoenix
Two big cats and three large birds − a cheetah, a mountain lion, a swamphen, a kookaburra and an Indian goose - from the Wildlife World Zoo and Aquarium, 20 miles west of Phoenix, died, and others were infected after being exposed to the bird flu, [according to USA TODAY's previous reporting.](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2024/12/13/bird-flu-arizona-zoo/76956233007/)
Maricopa County Department of Public Health officials transported the sick animals to the Arizona Department of Agriculture for testing which later indicated they were likely exposed to avian influenza.
Who is most at risk?
People who are most at risk of being infected by bird flu are those who work with poultry, waterfowl and dairy cows, according to [Cleveland Clinic](https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/22401-bird-flu#symptoms-and-causes). However, it is rare for the infection to spread from person to person.
While cases of bird flu in humans have been reported, the risk to the general public remains low, according to the CDC.
How does it spread?
A person can be infected with the virus if they touch an object that has been contaminated and then touch their eyes, nose, or mouth, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/bird-flu/prevention/farm-workers.html). The virus can also be spread through the handling of live and dead animals that are infected.
It can also be spread through eating, drinking or inhaling anything that contains the live virus like raw, [unpasteurized milk.](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/health/2024/12/08/raw-farm-quarantined-recall-raw-milk-bird-flu/76760105007/)
What are the symptoms?
The symptoms of those who have been infected with bird flu can range in severity, according to the CDC, from no symptoms or mild illness to severe disease resulting in death.
The following are symptoms of bird flu, according to the Cleveland Clinic and CDC:
- Pink eye
- Fever
- Fatigue
- Cough
- Muscle aches
- Sore throat
- Nausea
- Vomiting
- Diarrhea
- Stuffy or runny nose
- Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
- Headaches
- Pneumonia requiring hospitalization
How to avoid being infected
To avoid becoming sick with avian influenza, the CDC recommends the following:
- Avoid contact with sick or dead animals, especially wild birds or poultry.
- People who do have contact with dead animals should wear the recommended recommended personal protective equipment, PPE, which should be provided by an employer at no cost.
Julia is a trending reporter for USA TODAY. You can connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/juliamgomez/), follow her on [X,](https://twitter.com/JuliaMarieGZ) formerly known as Twitter, [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/juliamariegz/) and [TikTok](https://www.tiktok.com/@juliamariegz): @juliamariegz, or email her at jgomez@gannett.com

author: Mike Straw
title: Tomb Raider Developer Crystal Dynamics Holds Layoffs
text:
Crystal Dynamics, the developers behind the recent Tomb Raider games, has announced that it has held layoffs at the studio.
In an announcement on LinkedIn, the studio said that it made the “difficult decision” to let go 17 people from the company. In it’s statement, they said that the decision wasn’t made “lightly”.
“Ultimately, this step was necessary to better align our current business needs and the studio’s future success,” the statement reads. “It is not a reflection of the dedication or ability of those affected.
“We recognize how painful this outcome is for those impacted and we are supporting them with transition packages and opportunity outreach.”
The statement ended with the studio saying that it “remains committed to pushing the boundaries of making great games” nor does it change any of their current projects.
Insider Gaming has reached out to Crystal Dynamics for more details on the support and “transition packages” the impacted employees are receiving. Should a response be received, this story will be updated accordingly.
Crystal Dynamics is just the latest studio to hold layoffs in 2025. As of publishing, roughly 1,500 confirmed jobs have been lost across nearly 50 companies this year.
For more Insider Gaming, check out what popular map is returning to Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 in Season 3. And don’t forget to sign up for our newsletter.
